title-group.article-title: Modified intelligent genetic algorithm-based adaptive neural network control for uncertain structural systems

article-meta.aff: 1Institute of Maritime Information and Technology, National Kaohsiung Marine University, Kaohsiung, Taiwan
2Global Earth Observation and Data Analysis Center, National Cheng Kung University, Taiwan
3Department of Civil Engineering, National Central University, Taiwan

author-notes.corresp: Chen-Wu Chen, Institute of Maritime Information and Technology, National Kaohsiung Marine University, 482 Jhongjhou 3rd Road, Cijin District, Kaohsiung City, Kaohsiung 80543, Taiwan Email: chengwu@mail.nkmu.edu.tw

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The stability analysis of a genetic algorithm-based adaptive neural network controller for a nonlinear system is discussed. First, we track the reference trajectory for an uncertain and nonlinear plant. We make sure that it is well approximated and described using the structure of a radial based function network. Then, we decide on the initial values of the consequent parameter vector utilizing a genetic algorithm. Next, a modified adaptive neural network controller is proposed to simultaneously stabilize and control the system. A stability criterion is also derived from Lyapunov’s direct method to ensure the stability of the nonlinear system. Finally, we discuss an example and provide a numerical simulation. The results demonstrate that the control methodology can rapidly and efficiently control a complex and nonlinear system.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, many fuzzy control models have been proposed to solve various practical problems (Ali and Balasubramaniam, 2009; Chuang et al., 2009; Chung and Wu, 2009; Huang et al., 2009; Shakouri et al., 2009a,b; Soliman et al., 2009ab; Balasubramaniam et al., 2010; Esfahanipour and Aghamiri, 2010; and the references therein). It is believed that the tool of fuzzy models can be used to deal with engineering problems such as active control and structural control. Therefore, a new viewpoint using intelligent control is developed in this study.

Moreover, as explored in previous work, neural networks (NN) (Hecht-Nielsen, 1989; Yabuta and Yamada, 1991; Ku and Lee, 1995), can be designed to emulate the capabilities of the human brain, such as artificial neurons, synaptic weights and threshold. Many NN systems, which are essentially intelligent inference systems implemented in the framework of adaptive networks, have been developed to model or control nonlinear plants with remarkable results. The desired performance can be obtained with fewer adjustable parameters, although sometimes more training is required to achieve the higher accuracy derived from the transfer function and the learning algorithm. In addition to these features, NNs also act as a universal approximator (Hartman et al., 1990; Funahashi and Nakamura, 1993) where the feedforward network is very important. A backpropagation algorithm (Hecht-Nielsen, 1989; Ku and Lee, 1995), is usually used in the feedforward type of NN but heavy and complicated learning is needed to tune each network weight. Aside from the backpropagation type of NN, another common feedforward NN is the radial basis function network (RBFN) (Powell, 1987, 1992; Park and Sandberg, 1991).

RBFNs use only one hidden layer. The transfer function of the hidden layer is a nonlinear semi-affine function. Obviously, the learning rate of the RBFN will be faster than that of the backpropagation network. Furthermore, the RBFN can approximate any nonlinear continuous function and eliminate local minimum problems (Powell, 1987, 1992; Park and Sandberg, 1991). These features mean that the RBFN is usually used for real-time control in nonlinear dynamic systems. Some results indicate that, under certain mild function conditions, the RBFN is capable of universal approximations (Park and Sandberg, 1991; Powell, 1992).

Adaptive algorithms can be utilized to find the best high-performance parameters for the NN (Goodwin and Sin, 1984; Sanner and Slotine, 1992). Adaptive laws have been designed for the Lyapunov synthesis approach to tune the adjustable parameters of the RBFN, and analyze the stability of the overall system. A genetic algorithm (GA) (Goldberg, 1989; Chen, 1998), is the usual optimization technique used in the self-learning or training strategy to decide the initial values of the parameter vector. This GA-based modified adaptive neural network controller (MANNC) should improve the immediate response, the stability, and the robustness of the control system.

Another common problem encountered when switching the control input of the sliding model system is the so-called “chattering” phenomenon. The smoothing of control discontinuity inside a thin boundary layer essentially acts as a low-pass filter structure for the local dynamics, thus eliminating chattering (Utkin, 1978; Khalil, 1996). The laws are updated by the introduction of a boundary-layer function to cover parameter errors and modeling errors, and to guarantee that the state errors converge within a specified error bound (Chen et al., 2009a,b,d,f).

We focus on the design of a method for robust tracking control for that class of nonlinear uncertain systems involving external disturbances in this study. To meet these requirements we propose an NN controller with a decentralized RBFN structure. GAs and adaptive laws are used to produce a major reduction in the computational burden and improve control performance. The nonlinear system for the tracking of a reference trajectory for the plant is well approximated via radial basis function networks, with the initial parameter vector values being decided by the GA. After this, the designed adaptive control law and the boundary-layer function are utilized to update the parameters of the GA-based MANNC. Finally, both the tracking error and the modeling error are shown to approach zero.

sec.title: 2. Reference modeling for nonlinear dynamic systems
sec.p: The plant is a single-input/single-out nth-order system with n≥1. (1)x·1=x2,:xn-1=xn,x·n=f(x)+g(x)·u+d,y=x1, where x=[x1,x2,…,xn-1,xn]T∈Rn is the state vector of the system; u∈R is the control signal; f, g are smooth nonlinear functions; d denotes the external disturbance d(t) which is unknown but usually bounded.

The states x=[x1,x2,…,xn-1,xn]T are assumed to be available. For example, a single robot can be represented in the form of (1), with n = 2 and x(x1=θ,x2=θ·) being measurable. Differentiating the output with respect to time for n times (till the control input u appears), one obtains the input/output form of (1) y(n)=f(x)+g(x)·u+d(t).

The system is said to have a relative degree n, if g(x) is bounded away from zero.Assumption 1
g(x) is bounded away from zero over a compact set ζ⊂Rn, |g(x)|≥b>0,∀x∈ζ.

If the control goal is for the plant output y to track a reference trajectory yr, the reference control input r can be defined using the following reference model: (2)r=yr(n)+αn-1yr(n-1)+αn-2yr(n-2)+…+α1y·r+α0yr, where αn-1,αn-2,…,α1,α0 are chosen so that the polynomial ℓn+αn-1ℓn-1+αn-2ℓn-2+…+α1ℓ+α0 is Hurwitz, and ℓ here denotes the Laplace variable.
If f(x), g(x) are known, and Assumption 1 is satisfied, the control law can be defined as (3)u=-f(x)-d(x)-(αn-1y(n-1)+…+α1y·+α0y)+rg(x), ∀x∈S
Substituting (3) into (1), the linearized system becomes (yr(n)-y(n))+αn-1(yr(n-1)-y(n-1))+…+α1(y·r-y·) +α0(yr-y)=0.
If we define e=yr-y as the tracking error, then the reference control input (2) results in the following error equation: (4)e(n)+ αn-1e(n-1)+…+α1e·+α0e=0.

sec.title: 3. Radial basis function network
sec.p: The input/output representation of the RBFN with r in-puts and m outputs has the following form: (5)y(k)=∑i=1MwiR(x-miσ)=∑i=1Mwiexp[-(x-miσi)2], where M∈N, the set of natural numbers, is the number of nodes in the hidden layer; wi∈Rm is the vector of weights from the i th node to output nodes; x is an input vector (an element of Rr); exp(*) is a radially symmetric function of a unit in the hidden layer; and mi and σi are the center and width of the ith node, respectively.

A Gaussian function is often used as an activation function. The width of the nodes may be the same or may vary. RBF networks having the same form as in equation (5) have been utilized in several studies (Powell, 1987, 1992; Park and Sandberg, 1991). Some results indicate that, under certain mild conditions for the function R(*), RBFNs (as represented by equation (5)) are capable of universal approximations (Powell, 1992; Park and Sandberg, 1991. The structure of radial basis function networks is shown in Figure (1). Figure 1.
Structure of a radial basis function network.

In the RBFN, nodes in layer 1 are input nodes representing the input linguistic variables. Nodes in the hidden layer are transfer nodes which act like membership functions. Each transfer node is responsible for mapping the possibility distribution for an input linguistic variable. The last layer contains the output variable nodes obtained using a feedforward neural network. The links between the hidden layer nodes and output layer nodes are the consequence links, the connection weights are represented by w. The connection weights are tuned as the output action strength of the output associated with the transfer function. Moreover, all the consequence links are fully connected to the output layer nodes and can be interpreted as the strength of the output action. Thus, the overall net output is treated as a linear combination of the consequences of all rules.

sec.title: 4. Smooth control input
sec.p:
A pure sliding mode control which uses switching control laws can be a viable, high performance option. However, the “chattering” phenomenon (shown in Figure 2) is a common problem in the switching control input of a sliding mode control system. Although the tracking performance may be excellent it may only be obtained at the price of high control chattering. Figure 2.
Chattering phenomenon encountered using the switching control law.

How to derive control laws that maintain the system close to the sliding surface (S = 0) while avoiding chattering altogether is an important question to answer. In general, chattering must be eliminated for the controller to perform properly. As shown in Figure 3, this can be achieved by smoothing out control discontinuity in a thin boundary layer neighboring the switching surface B(t)={x|S(x;t)≤Φ},Φ>0, where Φ is the thickness of the boundary layer. Figure 3.
Sliding plant of a smooth controller.

sec.title: 5. GA-based MANNC for nonlinear systems
sec.p:
The GA-MANNC system is shown in Figure 4. It is known that an RBFN system can be used effectively for any nonlinear continuous function approximation. If f(x), g(x) are known, we can design an RBFN (6) to approximate u as follows: (6)u¯(w¯)=∑k=1mw¯kRk(S), where m is the sum of the hidden nodes; w¯k, i.e., |w¯k|≤wmax indicates the adjustable network weights between hidden nodes and output nodes; and R(S)=[R1(S),R2(S),…,Rm(S)]T is t the vector of radial basis function (Park and Sandberg, 1991), which is defined as (7)Rk=μk(S-Ck)∑k=1mμk(S-Ck),
(8)μk( ‖S-Ck‖)=exp(-( ‖S-Ck‖β)2).
Figure 4.
GA_ANNC system.

From the approximation property of the fuzzy system, an uncertain and nonlinear plant can be effectively approximated and described using the fuzzy model involving fuzzy logic control (FLC) rules to achieve the control object.Assumption 2
For x∈ζ⊂Rn, there exists an adjustable parameter vector w¯=[w¯1,w¯2,…,w¯n]T allowing the fuzzy system u¯(S,w¯)=w¯TR(S) to be approximated as a continuous function u with accuracy ɛmax over the set ζ, that is, ∃w¯, so that (9)sup|u¯(S,w¯)-u(S)|≤ɛmax,∀S∈ζ.

Let w∧ denote the estimate of w¯ at time t. Now we can define the estimated control output u∧(S,w∧) as (10)u∧(S,w∧)=∑k=1mw∧k·Rk(S)=w∧TR(S), and then decide on the initial values of the weight parameter vector w∧ based on the genetic algorithm. First define the parameter error vector at time t by w~=w¯-w∧, and then (11)w~TR(S)=u¯(S,w¯)-u∧(S,w∧).
According to Assumption 2 we can define the modeling error as (12)ɛ=u-u¯(S,w¯), where |ɛ|≤ɛmax.
We can say that (13)u=u∧(S,w∧)+w~TR(S)+ɛ.
Then, substituting (13) into (3), we obtain the error dynamic equation (14)e(n)+αn-1e(n-1)+…+α1e·+α0e=g(x)·(w~TR(S)+ɛ).

We now define the augmented error as (15)S=βn-1e(n-1)+…+β1e·+β0e, where βn-1,…,β1,β0 in (15), and αn-1,…,α1,α0 in (14) are chosen so that (16)M∧(ℓ)=βn-1ℓn-1+…+β1ℓ+β0ℓn+αn-1ℓn-1+…+α1ℓ+α0=N(ℓ)D(ℓ). is a strictly positive real (SPR) transfer function, and N(ℓ) and D(ℓ) are coprime.

If we define em=[e,…,e(n-1)]T as the states of (14), then (14) can be realized as (17)e·m(t)=Λ·em(t)+b·[g(x)·(w~TR(S)+ɛ)],
(18)S(t)=cTem(t), where Λ=[010…00001…00:::::000…10000…01-α0-α1-α2…-αn-2-αn-1]n×n, b=[00:001]n×1c=[β0 β1 … βn-1]T,letβn-1=1.

According to the Kalman-Yakubovich lemma, when M∧(ℓ) is SPR, there exist symmetric and positive definite matrices P and Q so that (19)PΛ+ΛTP=-Q,
(20)Pb=c,fori=1,…,p,

Next we shall investigate the asymptotic stability of the origin using the Lyapunov function candidates. First define a Lyapunov candidate function as (21)V(em,w~)=η·emTPem+w~TH11w~, where η is a positive constant representing the learning rate, w~=[w~1 w~2 … w~m]T,H11=g(x)·Im×m, and w~TH11=[g(x)·w~10…00g(x)·w~2…0::000…g(x)·w~m]m×m, m: the sum of the hidden nodes.

If emTPem>φ2, the derivate of V(em,w~) along the trajectories of the system should be negative definite for all nonlinearities that satisfy a given sector condition (Lyapunov stability). (22)V·(em,w~)=η·(e·mTPem+emTPe·m)+2w~TH11~·w.
As mentioned above, w~=w¯-w∧, and we can infer that ~·w=-∧·w, and (23)V·=η·(emTΛTPem+emTPΛem)+2η·emTPb·[g(x) ·(w~TR(S)+ɛ)]+2·w~TH11(-∧·w)=η·emT(-Q)em+2η·S·[g(x)·(w~TR(S)+ɛ)] +2·w~TH11(-∧·w).
To amend the modeling error ɛ and the chattering phenomenon, we propose a modified adaptive law (24) with which to tune the adjustable consequent parameters of the MANNC (24)∧·w=η·|S|·R·sat(S/Φ).
The thin boundary layer function sat(S/Φ) is defined as sat(S/Φ)={1,if(S/Φ)>1(S/Φ),if-1≤(S/Φ)≤1-1,if(S/Φ)<-1, where Φ>0 is the thickness of the boundary layer.
If we substitute (24) into (23), then (23) becomes V·=-η·emTQem+2η·S·[g(x)·(w~TR(S)+ɛ)] -2η·|S|·[g(x)·w~TR(S)]·sat(S/Φ).
When |S|>Φ, then V·=-η·emTQem+2η·emTc·(g(x)·ɛ)≤-η·‖em‖2·Q+2η·‖em‖·‖c‖·‖g(x)·ɛ‖≤-η·‖em‖·[‖em‖·Q-2‖c‖·‖g(x)·ɛ‖].
If μ is positive and small enough, then φ>0 and σ>0, as a result {φQP-2‖c‖·‖g(x)·ɛ‖}>σ, where emTPem>φ2.
It is true that V·≤-η·‖em‖·σ if emTPem>φ2 and |S|>Φ, and hence V·<0. Thus, V will gradually converge to zero as will all the ς.

Based on the above inference and the Lyapunov stability theory, em will gradually converge inside the bounded zone ‖em‖≤(φP,Φβ0). The tracking error and the modeling error will then both approach zero.

sec.title: 6. Numerical simulation
sec.p: In this section, the proposed GA-based MANNC is demonstrated with an example of the control methodology.

sec.title: 6.1. ATMD system
sec.p:
The active TMD mounted on a shear structure is modeled as a four-degree-of freedom structure-ATMD system as shown in Figure 5. The parameters md=50 (kg), cd=14.05 (N-s/m), and kd=9875.18 (N/m) represent mass, damping, and stiffness in the ATMD and the following parameter vectors: M (kg), C (N-s/m), and K (N/m), represent the mass, damping, and stiffness vectors (t: sec) of this dilapidated-simulation structure with ATMD; F and u represent the external force and control input. The dynamic equations of motion of the pendulum are given below. (25)[x··1x··2x··3x··d]=[(-M-1K)4×4(-M-1C)4×4][x1x2x3xdx·1x·2x·3x·d]+[00-1/m3-1/md]·u+[-1/m1-1/m2-1/m3-1/md]·F, where M=[980.710000980.710000980.71000050],K=[2740599(1-0.3t)-1640938(1-0.3t)368992(1-0.3t)0-1640938(1-0.3t)3020937(1-0.3t)-1624126(1-0.3t)0368992(1-0.3t)-1624126(1-0.3t)1333065(1-0.3t)+9875.2-9875.200-9875.29875.2],C=[382.65(1+0.1t)-57.27(1+0.1t)61.64(1+0.1t)0-57.27(1+0.1t)456.73(1+0.1t)-2.63(1+0.1t)061.64(1+0.1t)-2.63(1+0.1t)437.29(1+0.1t)+14.05-14.0500-14.054.05]. Figure 5.
Four-degree-of-freedom structure-Active Tuned Mass Damper (ATMD) system.

We set the sensor on the top floor of the dilapidated-simulation structure. Using the procedure discussed above, we specify the response of the control system by defining a suitable sliding surface S=cTem=30e3-0.2ed+e·3-0.4e·d. Then, we construct the structure of RBFN based on the genetic algorithm and the initial values of the consequent parameter vector w∧ can be chosen as follows: [1 0.88 0.60 0.25 0.05 0 −0.06 −0.25 −0.36 −0.72 −0.95]’. Apply the controller as given in equation (6) to control the nonlinear system (1). Next, let η=10, Φ=0.2, and adjust w∧ by the adaptive law as given by (24).

The simulation results in the El Centro earthquake disturbances are illustrated in Figures 6–8. It is shown to improve the performance of the system in all respects while retaining the advantage of assuring robustness in the presence of bounded disturbances. Figure 6.
Acceleration of the El Centro earthquake.
Figure 7.
Top floor response of the structure in the El Centro earthquake. Figure 8.
Control force of the ATMD system in the El Centro earthquake.

As can be seen in Figures 6–8, the dilapidated simulated structure rapidly becomes asymptotically stable and the modified adaptive neural network controller (MANNC) can be derived to simultaneously stabilize and control the system.

sec.title: 7. Conclusions
sec.p: Recently, soft computing and artificial intelligence have been successfully applied to the nonlinear system, such as robot manipulation, engineering application and construction managements (Almutairi and Zribi, 2009; Amini and Vahdani, 2009; Guclu and Metin, 2009; Hsu et al., 2011; Lin and Chao, 2009; Omurlu et al., 2009; Slotine and Li, 1991; Tu et al., 2009; Tusset et al., 2009; Zhao et al., 2009). Globalization and the speed of the internet mean that soft computing and its application are springing up for communications, biology, medicine, the humanities, management sciences, and similar fields. (Hsiao et al., 2005a,b,c,d,e; Chen et al., 2005a,b, 2006a,b,c, 2007a,b,c,d,e,f, 20008a,b,c,d,e, 2009a,b,c,d,e,f, 2010a,b,c,d,e,f,g,h, 2011a,b,c,d,e,f,g,h, 2012a,b,c,d,e,f,g,h; Chen, 2006, 2009a,b, 2010a,b; 2011a,b,c,d,e,f,g,h,i, 2012a,b,c,d,e,f,g,h,i; Hsieh et al., 2006; Tsai et al., 2008; Yang et al., 2008a,b; Yeh et al., 2008, 2012; Lin et al., 2009a,b; 2011a,b, 2012a,b; Chen and Chen, 2010a,b; Chen and Saif, 2010; Chiang et al., 2010; Lee, 2010; Lee et al., 2010a,b, 2011a,b,c; Li et al., 2010; Lin and Chen, 2010, 2011, 2012; Liu et al., 2010, 2011a,b, 2012a,b,c; Shih et al., 2010a,b,c, 2011a,b,c,d,e,f,g; Solihin et al., 2010; Ahmadian and Azizi, 2011; Abd-Alla et al., 2011; Chen and Huang, 2011; Cheng et al., 2011; Chiang and Wang, 2011; Chiou et al., 2011; Chu et al., 2011; Jayaswal et al., 2011; Kuo et al., 2011; Kuo and Chen, 2011, 2012a,b; Marichal et al., 2011; Metin and Guclu, 2011; Shen et al., 2011; Soundarrajan and Sumathi, 2011; Tang et al., 2011; Tsai and Chen, 2011a,b; Yu et al., 2011a,b; Lee and Chen, 2012; Su et al., 2012; Tseng and Chen, 2012; Tseng et al., 2012a,b,c; Yang and Chen, 2012; Zhang et al., 2010a,b, 2011a,b,c,d; Zhao 2010a,b, 2011a,b; Zheng et al., 2011; Zhu et al., 2011). In general, the biggest difficulty when designing a neural network controller (NNC) that is capable of rapidly and efficiently controlling complex and nonlinear systems is how to select the most appropriate initial values for the parameter vector. In this study, we propose a method of stability analysis for a GA-based modified adaptive NNC capable of handling these types of problems for a nonlinear system. First of all, an uncertain and nonlinear plant for the tracking of a reference trajectory is accurately approximated via radial basis function networks. Next, the initial values of the consequent parameter vector are chosen through a genetic algorithm after which a modified adaptive law is derived based on the Lyapunov stability theory to control the nonlinear system for tracking a user-defined reference model. A boundary-layer function is introduced into these updating laws to cover parameter and modeling errors, and to guarantee that the state errors converge into a specified error bound. After this, an MANNC is derived to simultaneously stabilize and control the system. Finally, a numerical simulation is carried out to demonstrate the rapidity and efficiency with which the control methodology can control nonlinear systems.
